children.name: Field - Discovering Statistics
children.description: This folder contains the data sets from Field, A. P. (2017). Discovering Statistics Using IBM SPSS Statistics (5th ed.). London: Sage. These data sets were constructed by Andy Field who therefore owns the copyright. Andy Field generously agreed that we can include these data sets in the JASP data library. These data sets are also publicly available on the website that accompanies Andy Field's book: https://edge.sagepub.com/field5e. Without Andy Field's explicit consent, these data sets may not be distributed for commercial purposes, these data sets may not be edited, and these data sets may not be presented without acknowledging their source (i.e., the terms of a CC BY-NC-ND license

children.name: Album Sales
children.description:
Factors that may influence album sales.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Alcohol Attitudes
children.description:
Attitudes towards water, wine, and beer after watching positive, neutral, or negative imagery of that drink - each participant features in each cell of the 3x3 design.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Beer Goggles
children.description:
Median attractiveness ratings of 50 attractive or unattractive faces after consuming different amounts of alcohol.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Bush Tucker Food
children.description:
The number of seconds before celebrities retch while eating disgusting food - each celebrity consumed four different kinds of disgusting items.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Dancing Cats
children.description:
The number of cats who learned to dance, trained by one of two types of conditioning.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Dancing Cats and Dogs
children.description:
The number of cats and dogs who learned to dance, trained by one of two types of conditioning.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Exam Anxiety
children.description:
Questionnaire of students prior to an exam (variables are anxiety, preparedness, and grade).

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Fear of Statistics
children.description:
Responses of 2571 students on an SPSS Anxiety Questionnaire.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Invisibility Cloak
children.description:
The number of mischievous acts committed by two groups of people, those with and those without an invisibility cloak.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Looks or Personality
children.description:
Preference scores of ten men and ten women for nine speed-dating partners who varied in attractiveness (high, average, low) and charisma (high, some, none).

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: The Biggest Liar
children.description:
Creativity test scores and ranking in a lying competition.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Viagra
children.description:
Men's libido (and that of their partners) after having been administered different doses of Viagra.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Moore, McCabe, & Craig - Introduction to the Practice of Statistics
children.path: Moore, McCabe, & Craig - Introduction to the Practice of Statistics
children.description: This folder contains the data sets from Moore, D. S., McCabe, G. P., & Craig, B. A. (2012). Introduction to the Practice of Statistics (7th ed.). New York: W. H. Freeman and Company. Moore, McCabe, and Craig generously agreed that we can include the data sets in the JASP data library. These data sets are also publicly available on the website that accompanies their book: whfreeman.com/ips7e. Without the authors' explicit consent, these data sets may not be distributed for commercial purposes, these data sets may not be edited, and these data sets may not be presented without acknowledging their source (i.e., the terms of a CC BY-NC-ND license

children.name: College Success
children.description:
High school grades, SAT scores, and Grade Point Average of 224 university students.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Directed Reading Activities
children.description:
Reading performance of two groups of pupils - one control group and one group that was given Directed Reading Activities.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Facebook Friends
children.description:
Preference ratings for Facebook profiles - five groups judge the same profiles, except for the aspect that was manipulated: the number of friends for that profile.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Fidgeting and Fat Gain
children.description:
Fat gain of participants and their non-deliberate exercise activities.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Health Habits
children.description:
Physical activity and consumption of fruits of 1184 students.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Heart Rate
children.description:
Heart rate of male and female runners and generally sedentary participants following 6 minutes of exercise.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Moon and Aggression
children.description:
The number of disruptive behaviors by dementia patients during two different phases of the lunar cycle.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Physical Activity and BMI
children.description:
Participants' Body Mass Index and average daily number of steps.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Response to Eye Color
children.description:
Post-advertisement attitudes towards a brand expressed by four different groups - each group saw the same advertisement except for the aspect that was manipulated: the eye-color of the model.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Weight Gain
children.description:
Weight of 16 participants before and after an eight-week period of excessive calorie intake.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Sleep
children.description:
The number of additional hours that each of ten patients slept after having been administered two 'soporific drugs' (i.e., sleeping pills).

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of descriptive statistics.

Data set included in R.

children.name: Directed Reading Activities
children.description:
Reading performance of two groups of pupils - one control group and one group that was given Directed Reading Activities.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of an independent samples t-test.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Eye Movements
children.description:
The number of correctly recalled words by two groups of participants - during the retention interval, one group was instructed to fixate on a centrally presented dot

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian independent samples t-test.

Subset of the data reported in Matzke et al. (2015).

children.name: Invisibility Cloak
children.description:
The number of mischievous acts committed by two groups of people, those with and those without an invisibility cloak.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of an independent samples t-test.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Kitchen Rolls
children.description:
Openness to Experience scores for two groups of students - while filling out the personality questionnaire, both groups rotated a kitchen roll with their hands (one group clockwise, the other group counterclockwise).

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian and frequentist versions of independent samples t-test.

Data reported in Wagenmakers et al. (2015).

children.name: Moon and Aggression
children.description:
The number of disruptive behaviors by dementia patients during two different phases of the lunar cycle.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a paired samples t-test.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Stereograms
children.description:
The time it took two groups of participants to see the objects hidden in a stereogram - one group received advance information about the scene, the other group did not.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian independent samples t-test.

Data reported in Frisby & Clatworthy (1975).

children.name: Weight Gain
children.description:
Weight of 16 participants before and after an eight-week period of excessive calorie intake.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a one sample t-test.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Alcohol Attitudes
children.description:
Attitudes towards water, wine, and beer after watching positive, neutral, or negative imagery of that drink - each participant features in each cell of the 3x3 design.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a repeated measures ANOVA.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Beer Goggles
children.description:
Median attractiveness ratings of 50 attractive or unattractive faces after consuming different amounts of alcohol.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of an ANOVA.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Bugs
children.description:
The extent to which people want to kill arthropods that vary in freighteningness (low, high) and disgustingness (low, high) - each participant rates their attitude for all arthropods.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a mixed design ANOVA.

Subset of the data reported in Ryan, Wilde, & Crist (2013).

children.name: Bush Tucker Food
children.description:
The number of seconds before celebrities retch while eating disgusting food - each celebrity consumed four different kinds of disgusting items.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a repeated measures ANOVA.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Erotic Pictures and Love
children.description:
Men and women's feelings towards their partners after watching either erotic or artistic pictures.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a factorial 2 x 2 ANOVA.

Subset of the data reported in Balzarini et al. (2016).

children.name: Facebook Friends
children.description:
Preference ratings for Facebook profiles - five groups judge the same profiles, except for the aspect that was manipulated: the number of friends for that profile.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a one-way ANOVA.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Heart Rate
children.description:
Heart rate of male and female runners and generally sedentary participants following 6 minutes of exercise.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a 2 x 2 between subjects ANOVA.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Looks or Personality
children.description:
Preference scores of ten men and ten women for nine speed-dating partners who varied in attractiveness (high, average, low) and charisma (high, some, none).

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a mixed design ANOVA.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Pain Thresholds
children.description:
Pain threshold for people with different hair color.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a one-way ANOVA.

Data from McClave & Dietrich (1991).

children.name: Response to Eye Color
children.description:
Post-advertisement attitudes towards a brand expressed by four different groups - each group saw the same advertisement except for the aspect that was manipulated: the eye-color of the model.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a one-way ANOVA.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Singers
children.description:
"Heights in inches of the singers in the New York Choral Society in 1979. The data are grouped according to voice part. The vocal range for each voice part increases in pitch according to the following order: Bass 2, Bass 1, Tenor 2, Tenor 1, Alto 2, Alto 1, Soprano 2, Soprano 1."

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian between subjects ANOVA.

Data set included in R.

children.name: Tooth Growth
children.description:
"The response is the length of odontoblasts (cells responsible for tooth growth) in 60 guinea pigs. Each animal received one of three dose levels of vitamin C (0.5, 1, and 2 mg/day) by one of two delivery methods, orange juice or ascorbic acid (a form of vitamin C and coded as VC)."

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a 2 x 2 ANOVA.

Data set included in R.

children.name: Viagra
children.description:
Men's libido (and that of their partners) after having been administered different doses of Viagra.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of an ANCOVA.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Adam Sandler
children.description:
Rotten Tomatoes ratings and box office success for movies featuring Adam Sandler.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian Pearson's correlation.

Data collected from Rotten Tomatoes in 2015 by E.J. Wagenmakers.

children.name: Album Sales
children.description:
Factors that may influence album sales.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of linear regression.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Auction
children.description:
The selling price and age of antique clocks, and the number of bidders in the auction.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of linear regression.

Data from Mendenhall & Sincich (1993).

children.name: Big Five Personality Traits
children.description:
Scores on Big Five personality traits of 500 participants.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of Pearson's correlation.

Data reported in Dolan et al. (2009).

children.name: College Success
children.description:
High school grades, SAT scores, and Grade Point Average of 224 university students.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of linear regression.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Exam Anxiety
children.description:
Questionnaire of students prior to an exam (variables are anxiety, preparedness, and grade).

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Pearson correlation coefficient.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Fidgeting and Fat Gain
children.description:
Fat gain of participants and their non-deliberate exercise activities.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of linear regression.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Glasgow Norms
children.description:
A set of normative ratings for 5,553 English words on nine psycholinguistic dimensions.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of Bayesian correlations.

Data from Scott et al. (2017).

children.name: Physical Activity and BMI
children.description:
Participants' Body Mass Index and average daily number of steps.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of linear regression.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Presidents' Height
children.description:
Heights of US presidents and their proportion of the popular vote.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of conducting an interval-null hypothesis.

Subset of the data reported in Stulp et al. (2015).

children.name: World Happiness
children.description:
National happiness scores and various life factors of 155 countries reported in 2017.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of Bayesian linear regression.

Data from Helliwell, Layard, & Sachs (2017).

children.name: The Biggest Liar
children.description:
Creativity test scores and ranking in a lying competition.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of Spearman's and Kendall's correlation.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Titanic
children.description:
Age, cabin class, and survival status of 1313 passengers on the Titanic.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of logistic regression.

Data set included in R.

children.name: Dancing Cats and Dogs
children.description:
The number of cats and dogs who learned to dance, trained by one of two types of conditioning.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a log-linear analysis.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Dancing Cats
children.description:
The number of cats who learned to dance, trained by one of two types of conditioning.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a chi-squared test of independence.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: Death Penalty
children.description:
Court decisions on a death penalty (i.e., yes or no) split by race of a defendant (i.e., White or Black) and the race of the victim (i.e., White or Black).

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian log-linear analysis.

Data from Radelet & Pierce (1991).

children.name: Emily Rosa
children.description:
Correct and incorrect decisions from therapeutic touch practitioners in Emily Rosa's famous experiment. "In the initial trial, the subjects stated the correct location of the investigator's hand in 70 (47%) of 150 tries."

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian binomial test.

Data set reconstructed from the summary information in Rosa et al. (1998).

children.name: Health Habits
children.description:
Physical activity and consumption of fruits of 1184 students.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a chi-squared test of independence.

Data from Moore, McCabe, & Craig.

children.name: Hungry Zombies
children.description:
Answers of 12 zombies to the question: "what is your appetitive state?"

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian binomial test.

Fictional data from E.J. Wagenmakers.

children.name: Listerism
children.description:
Recovery status of patients treated with either Lister's method or ordinary dressings.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of Bayesian contingency tables.

Data set reconstructed from the summary information by MacAlister (1881) and reported in Jamil et al. (2017).

children.name: Memory of Life Stresses
children.description:
The number of reported life stresses (summed across participants) that occurred in specific months prior to an interview.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a multinomial test.

Subset of the data reported in Uhleman et al. (1974) provided by Haberman (1978).

children.name: MOOC Bias
children.description:
Response rate from MOOC lecturers to questions posed by eight constructed identities [i.e., gender (male, female) x race (White, Indian, Black, Chinese)].

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a chi-squared test of independence.

Data from Baker et al. (2018).

children.name: Sun Block Lotions
children.description:
Responses of 20 participants to the question: "Which of these two sun block lotions is better?"

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a binomial test.

Fictional data from Moore, McCaib, & Craig (2012).

children.name: Three-Sided Coin
children.description:
The number of times that each of two experimental coins landed on its edge (out of 1,000 tosses).

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian binomial test using summary statistics.

Data collected by Matthew Parker.

children.name: G Factor
children.description:
Charles Spearman's data of pupils' school grades and sensory discrimination scores.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of an exploratory factor analysis.

Data reported in Spearman (1904).

children.name: Tests of Controls
children.description:
A fictitious population of 100 control systems and relevant requirements.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of the Bayesian audit workflow.

Data set used in R package jfa

children.name: Testing for Overstatements
children.description:
A fictitious population consisting of 3500 transactions.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of the Bayesian audit workflow.

Data set used in R package jfa

children.name: Planning and Selecting a Sample
children.description:
A fictitious population consisting of 3500 transactions.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of the Bayesian planning and the selection analysis.

Data set used in R package jfa

children.name: Evaluating a Sample
children.description:
A fictitious audit sample consisting of 60 transactions.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian evaluation analysis.

Data set used in R package jfa

children.name: Assessing Benford's Law
children.description:
Financial Statemens of Sino Forest Corporationâ€™s 2010 Report.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a Benford's law analysis.

Data set used in R package benford.analysis

children.name: BuildIt Binary
children.description:
BuildIt's audit population consisting of 3500 transactions.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of the Bayesian audit workflow.

Data set used in R package jfa

children.name: One Sample T-Test
children.description:
This JASP file demonstrates a Bain one sample t-test using the Sesame Street data.

Data set included in the bain R package.

children.name: Welch's T-Test
children.description:
This JASP file demonstrates a Bain Welch's t-test using the Sesame Street data.

Data set included in the bain R package.

children.name: Paired Samples T-Test
children.description:
This JASP file demonstrates a Bain paired samples t-test using the Sesame Street data.

Data set included in the bain R package.

children.name: ANOVA
children.description:
This JASP file demonstrates a Bain ANOVA using the Sesame Street data.

Data set included in the bain R package.

children.name: ANCOVA
children.description:
This JASP file demonstrates a Bain ANCOVA using the Sesame Street data.

Data set included in the bain R package.

children.name: Regression
children.description:
This JASP file demonstrates a Bain regression using the Sesame Street data.

Data set included in the bain R package.

children.name: Structural Equation Modeling
children.description:
This JASP file demonstrates a Bain Structural Equation Model using the Sesame Street data.

Data set included in the bain R package.

children.name: Distributions
children.description:
Synthetic data set of variables generated from various probability distributions.

The example JASP file demonstrates the Normal distribution.

Fictional data created by JASP Team.

children.name: Iris Flowers
children.description:
This famous (Fisher's or Anderson's) iris data set gives the measurements in centimeters of the variables sepal length and width and petal length and width, respectively, for 50 flowers from each of 3 species of iris. The species are Iris setosa, versicolor, and virginica.

Data set included in R.

children.name: Telco Customer Churn
children.description:
Telecom data from 7043 customers of a phone provider. Variables range from personal descriptives to subscription fees and provide information on customer churning behaviour.

Publicly available at https://www.kaggle.com/blastchar/telco-customer-churn.

children.name: Student Grades
children.description:
Data contains information of 357 high school students in Portugal (Cortez & Silva, 2008).

Publicly available at https://www.kaggle.com/dipam7/student-grade-prediction

children.name: Wine Types
children.description:
The results of a chemical analysis of wines grown in a specific area of Italy. Three types of wine are represented in the 178 samples, with the results of 13 chemical analyses recorded for each sample.

Data set included in R.

children.name: BCG Vaccine
children.description:
Test statistics from studies examining the effectiveness of a BCG vaccine.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a fixed-effects and random-effects meta-analysis.

Data courtesy of Raoul Grasman.

children.name: BFI Network
children.description:
Responses from 2,800 participants on 25 Big Five Inventory items.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a network analysis.

Data set included in R.

children.name: Fear of Statistics
children.description:
Responses of 2571 students on an SPSS Anxiety Questionnaire.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of a classical unidimensional reliability analysis.

Fictional data from Andy Field.

children.name: ASRM - Mania Scale
children.description: Responses of 78 participants to the Altman Self-Rating Mania Scale (ASRM), from Nicolai & Moshagen (2018). The file demonstrates the use of a Bayesian unidimensional reliability analysis

children.name: Interrater Data from Shrout and Fleiss (1979)
children.path: Interrater Data from Shrout and Fleiss (1979).jasp
children.description: Hypothetical data set from a paper on ICCs by Shrout and Fleiss (1979). The file demonstrates the use of classical intraclass correlation coefficients
children.associated_datafile: Interrater Data from Shrout and Fleiss (1979).csv

children.name: Political Democracy
children.description:
Indicators of industralization in 1960, and political democracy in 1960 and 1965.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of structural equation modeling.

Data set included in R.

children.name: Grand Point Average
children.description:
Grand Point Average of 200 college students across 6 semesters, along with information on gender, high school GPA and whether they were admitted to their university of choice.

The JASP file currently does not contain any analysis.

Data from Hox, Moerbeek, and Van de Schoot (2017).

children.name: Social Participation
children.description:
Measurements of Social Participation (church membership, memberships in voluntary organizations, and number of friends seen), as well as measures on potential causes of social interaction (income, occupation and education).

The JASP file currently does not contain any analysis.

Simulated data based on Hodge and Treiman (1986).

children.name: JASP Webpage Visits
children.description:
Number of visits to the JASP website from January to October 2020.

Data set collected by the JASP team.

children.name: Anscombe's Quartet
children.description:
A classic example of the need to visualize one's data.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of inspecting data thoroughly using plots rather than statistical output.

Fictional data from Anscombe (1973).

children.name: The Datasaurus Dozen (Long)
children.description:
Twelve variable pairs with the same summary statistics (i.e., means, standard deviations, and Pearson correlation coefficients) but dramatically different distributions.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of data visualization.

Synthetic data from Matejka & Fitzmaurice (2018). Data set included in R (Locke & McGowan, 2018).

children.name: The Datasaurus Dozen (Wide)
children.description:
Twelve variable pairs with the same summary statistics (i.e., means, standard deviations, and Pearson correlation coefficients) but dramatically different distributions.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of data visualization.

Synthetic data from Matejka & Fitzmaurice (2018). Data set included in R (Locke & McGowan, 2018).

children.name: Missing Data
children.description:
Synthetic data with missing values.

The example JASP file demonstrates the use of missing values.

Fictional data from Alexander Ly.

children.name: Debug Dataset (JASP Team, 2017)
children.description: For testing. Readme: is.gd/jaspdata
